name: Routine Biochemical Tests
hematology:
Full Blood Count (FBC)

  • Hemoglobin (Hb):
    - Microcytic Anemia: Iron deficiency (Chronic GI bleed/cancer) or Thalassemia.
    - Normocytic Anemia: Chronic disease, acute blood loss.
    - Macrocytic Anemia: B12/Folate deficiency, Alcohol, Hypothyroidism.
  • White Cell Count (WBC):
    - Neutrophilia: Bacterial infection, inflammation, tissue necrosis (pancreatitis/infarction), trauma (surgery).
    - Lymphocytosis: Viral infection, chronic infections (TB), lymphoma.
    - Leukopenia: Sepsis (bone marrow suppression), Chemotherapy, Hypersplenism.
  • Platelets:
    - Thrombocytopenia: Sepsis, DIC, massive transfusion (dilutional), hypersplenism. Risk of spontaneous bleeding if <20.
    - Thrombocytosis: Reactive (infection/bleed), Malignancy, Essential Thrombocythemia.
biochemistry:
Urea & Electrolytes (U&E)

  • Sodium (Na+): Hyponatremia is common post-op (SIADH, fluid overload). Hypernatremia indicates dehydration (free water loss).
  • Potassium (K+):
    - Hyperkalemia (>5.5): Surgical emergency (arrhythmia/cardiac arrest). Causes: Renal failure, Acidosis, Tissue necrosis (rhabdomyolysis/burns), Succinylcholine. Rx: Calcium gluconate (stabilize heart), Insulin/Dextrose (shift K+).
    - Hypokalemia (<3.5): Ileus, muscle weakness, arrhythmias. Causes: Vomiting, Diarrhea, Loop diuretics.
  • Urea & Creatinine:
    - Creatinine: Specific for renal function.
    - Urea: Raised in dehydration, GI bleed (digested blood protein), and catabolism. Isolated Urea Rise: Strong indicator of Upper GI Bleed or Dehydration.
liver_profile:
Liver Function Tests (LFTs)

  • Bilirubin:
    - Unconjugated: Pre-hepatic (Hemolysis, Gilbert's).
    - Conjugated: Post-hepatic (Obstruction).
  • Enzymes:
    - ALT/AST (Transaminases): Hepatocellular damage (Viral hepatitis, Ischemia, Paracetamol). ALT is more liver-specific.
    - ALP (Alkaline Phosphatase): Biliary obstruction (Cholestasis), Bone disease (Paget's/Mets). Check GGT to confirm liver origin.
  • Synthetic Function:
    - Albumin: Long half-life (20 days). Low in chronic liver disease, malnutrition, sepsis (capillary leak).
    - INR/PT: Short half-life (hours). Best marker for acute liver failure.
inflammatory:
Markers

  • CRP (C-Reactive Protein): Produced by liver in response to IL-6. Lags 12-24h behind clinical state.
    - Surgical Rule: CRP >150 mg/L on Post-op Day 3-4 is highly predictive of an anastomotic leak or septic complication.
  • Amylase: Diagnostic for Acute Pancreatitis (>3x upper limit). Non-specific (raised in perf ulcer, bowel ischemia). Short half-life.
  • Lipase: More specific and sensitive for pancreatitis. Stays elevated longer than amylase.
tumor_markers:
Common Markers

  • CEA: Colorectal Cancer (monitoring recurrence).
  • CA 19-9: Pancreatic & Biliary Cancer (Cholangiocarcinoma).
  • AFP: Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC) & Testicular Teratoma.
  • PSA: Prostate Cancer (and BPH/Prostatitis).
  • CA 125: Ovarian Cancer.
  • Calcitonin: Medullary Thyroid Cancer.

name: Routine Imaging Studies
xray:
Plain Radiography

  • Principles: Ionizing radiation. Denser tissue (bone) appears white; gas appears black.
  • Chest X-ray (CXR):
    - Erect: Detection of Pneumoperitoneum (free air under diaphragm) in perforated viscus.
    - Diagnosis: Pneumonia, Pleural effusion, Pulmonary edema.
  • Abdominal X-ray (AXR):
    - Indications: Suspected Intestinal Obstruction (dilated loops, air-fluid levels), Toxic Megacolon, Foreign body.
    - Limitations: Poor for gallstones (only 10% radio-opaque) or renal stones (KUB better).
ultrasound:
Ultrasound (USG)

  • Principles: High-frequency sound waves. No radiation. Safe in pregnancy/kids.
  • Uses:
    - Hepatobiliary: First-line for Gallstones (acoustic shadowing) and Biliary dilation.
    - Renal: Hydronephrosis, Bladder volume.
    - Scrotum/Gynae: Torsion, Ovarian cysts.
    - FAST Scan: Trauma (free fluid).
  • Limitations: Operator dependent. Poor visualization in obesity or through bowel gas/bone.
ct_scan:
Computed Tomography (CT)

  • Principles: Rotating X-ray beams creating cross-sectional slices. High radiation dose (~10mSv = 400 CXRs).
  • Contrast:
    - Intravenous (Iodine): Highlights vessels and organ perfusion. Phases: Arterial (Pancreas/Kidney), Portal Venous (Liver mets), Delayed (Ureters).
    - Oral (Gastrografin/Water): Distinguishes bowel loops from abscesses.
  • Indications: Gold standard for Acute Abdomen (Diverticulitis, Appendicitis in elderly), Trauma (Pan-scan), Cancer Staging (TAP), CT Angiography (GI Bleed).
  • Risks: Contrast Induced Nephropathy (CIN) - Check eGFR! Anaphylaxis. Radiation.
mri:
Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

  • Principles: Strong magnetic fields align protons. Radiofrequency pulses create images. No radiation.
  • Uses:
    - MRCP: Non-invasive visualization of biliary tree (stones/strictures).
    - Rectal Cancer: Staging (Mesorectal fascia involvement).
    - Pelvic Floor: Fistula-in-Ano (Parks classification).
    - Liver: Characterizing indeterminate lesions (Hemangioma vs Met).
  • Contraindications: Pacemakers, Cochlear implants, Metallic foreign bodies (eye), Claustrophobia.
pet_scan:
Positron Emission Tomography (PET-CT)

  • Principles: Functional imaging using radiolabeled glucose (18-FDG). Tumors/Infection are metabolically active and take up FDG ("Hot spots").
  • Uses: Staging malignancy (occult metastases), monitoring response to chemotherapy, differentiating fibrosis from recurrence.

name: Endoscopic Procedures
upper_gi:
Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (OGDS)

  • Scope: Visualizes Esophagus, Stomach, Duodenum (to D2).
  • Diagnostic: Biopsy (Gastric Ca, H. pylori, Celiac), Surveillance (Barrett's, Varices).
  • Therapeutic:
    - Hemostasis: Adrenaline injection, Heater probe, Clips (Ulcers), Banding (Varices).
    - Strictures: Balloon dilation, Stenting (Esophageal Ca).
  • Complications: Perforation (rare diagnostic, higher therapeutic), Aspiration, Bleeding.

ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography)

  • Scope: Side-viewing duodenoscope. Cannulates Ampulla of Vater. Fluoroscopy (X-ray) used.
  • Therapeutic (Mainly): Sphincterotomy (cut muscle), Stone extraction (Basket/Balloon), Stenting (Strictures/Tumors).
  • Complications: Pancreatitis (5-10%), Cholangitis, Hemorrhage, Perforation (duodenal).

EUS (Endoscopic Ultrasound)

  • Scope: US probe on tip. Close proximity to organs.
  • Uses: T-Staging (Esophageal/Pancreatic Ca depth), N-Staging (Biopsy/FNA of mediastinal/celiac nodes), Choledocholithiasis (if MRCP equivocal).
lower_gi:
Colonoscopy

  • Scope: Visualizes Rectum to Cecum (+ Terminal Ileum).
  • Indications: Colorectal Ca screening, IBD diagnosis, Polyps, Lower GI bleed.
  • Therapeutic: Polypectomy (Snare/Diathermy), Stenting, Decompression (Volvulus).
  • Prep: Full bowel preparation (laxatives) required.
  • Risks: Perforation (1:1000 diagnostic, higher therapeutic), Bleeding (delayed up to 10 days).

Flexible Sigmoidoscopy

  • Scope: Visualizes Rectum and Sigmoid (limited to 60cm).
  • Uses: Quick screen for distal disease, hemorrhoids. Only requires enema prep.

name: Shock
definition:
Definition

Acute circulatory failure leading to inadequate tissue perfusion and cellular hypoxia. It is defined by perfusion (mental state, urine output, lactate), not just blood pressure.
classification:
Types of Shock

  • Hypovolemic: Decreased intravascular volume.
    Causes: Hemorrhage, Burns, Dehydration.
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↓, CO ↓, SVR ↑ (Vasoconstriction).
  • Cardiogenic: Primary pump failure.
    Causes: MI, Arrhythmia, Valve failure.
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↑ (JVP raised), CO ↓, SVR ↑.
  • Obstructive: Extracardiac physical blockage.
    Causes: Tension Pneumothorax, Cardiac Tamponade, Massive PE.
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↑, CO ↓, SVR ↑.
  • Distributive: Peripheral vasodilation (Relative hypovolemia).
    Causes: Sepsis, Anaphylaxis, Neurogenic (Spinal cord injury).
    Hemodynamics: Preload ↓, CO ↑ (Hyperdynamic early), SVR ↓↓↓ (Warm peripheries).
hemorrhage_classes:
ATLS Classification of Hemorrhage

  • Class I (<15% / <750ml): Normal vitals. Slightly anxious.
  • Class II (15-30% / 750-1500ml): Tachycardia (>100), Narrow pulse pressure, Urine output normal.
  • Class III (30-40% / 1500-2000ml): Hypotension, Tachycardia (>120), Confusion, Urine <15ml/hr. (Requires Blood).
  • Class IV (>40% / >2000ml): Lethargic/Coma, Anuric, Severe Hypotension. (Immediate threat).
management:
Management Principles

1. Recognition: Tachycardia is the earliest sign. Hypotension is a late sign.
2. Resuscitation (ABCDE):
- Access: 2 Large bore (14/16G) IV cannulas.
- Fluids: Warmed Crystalloids (Hartmann's). 1L stat.
- Blood: If Class III/IV or non-responder. Use Massive Transfusion Protocol (1 RBC : 1 FFP : 1 Platelet).
3. Vasopressors: Noradrenaline (First line for Septic Shock after adequate fluid loading). Do not use in hypovolemia until filled.

name: Metabolic Response to Injury
phases:
1. Ebb Phase (0-24 hours)

Goal: Immediate survival.
Features: Hypometabolism, Decreased Cardiac Output, Decreased Temp, Vasoconstriction, Insulin levels drop.
Priority: Resuscitation (Stop bleeding, give fluids).

2. Flow Phase (Days to Weeks)

Goal: Repair and Recovery.
Catabolic Stage: Hypermetabolism (High CO, High Temp). Muscle wasting (protein breakdown) to provide glucose (Gluconeogenesis). Insulin Resistance (Stress Diabetes). Retention of Na+ and Water (ADH/Aldosterone).
Anabolic Stage: Recovery, weight gain, restoration of protein stores.
mediators:
Neuro-Endocrine Response

Afferent Nerves: Pain stimuli trigger Hypothalamus.
Hormones:
- Catabolic (Counter-regulatory): Cortisol, Glucagon, Adrenaline, Growth Hormone. (Drive glucose up).
- Anabolic: Insulin (But resistance prevents its action).
Cytokines: IL-1, IL-6, TNF-alpha (Cause fever, anorexia, acute phase proteins like CRP).
optimization:
Modifying the Response (ERAS)

The response is obligatory but can be attenuated.
1. Analgesia: Blocks afferent neural stimuli (Epidural).
2. Early Nutrition: Prevents starvation/gut barrier failure.
3. Minimally Invasive Surgery: Reduces tissue trauma/cytokine release.
4. Temperature Control: Preventing hypothermia reduces coagulopathy and stress.

name: Wound Healing
process:
Phases of Healing

  • 1. Hemostasis (Minutes): Vasoconstriction, Platelet plug formation, Fibrin clot (scaffold).
  • 2. Inflammation (Days 1-4): Neutrophils enter (kill bacteria) followed by Macrophages (key cell - debride and secrete growth factors). Clinical: Red, Hot, Swollen, Painful.
  • 3. Proliferation (Days 4-21):
    - Fibroblasts: Lay down Collagen Type III (weak/disorganized).
    - Angiogenesis: New vessels formation.
    - Epithelialization: Keratinocytes migrate over defect.
    - Granulation Tissue: Beefy red tissue (loops of capillaries + collagen).
  • 4. Remodeling (3 weeks - 1 year): Collagen Type III replaced by stronger Type I. Cross-linking. Scar contracts and fades. Strength reaches max 80% of original skin.
classifications:
Types of Union

Primary Intention: Clean wound edges approximated by sutures/staples. Minimal scarring. Rapid healing.
Secondary Intention: Wound left open (e.g., abscess, dirty trauma). Heals from bottom up by granulation and contraction. Slow, large scar.
Tertiary Intention (Delayed Primary): Wound left open initially (to allow infection/edema to resolve) then sutured closed after 3-5 days.
factors:
Factors Affecting Healing

Systemic: Age, Diabetes (microvascular disease/infection), Malnutrition (Protein, Vit C, Zinc deficiency), Steroids (inhibit collagen), Smoking (hypoxia/vasoconstriction), Jaundice, Uremia.
Local: Infection (most common cause of delay), Ischemia, Foreign body, Tension, Hematoma, Radiation.

name: Preparation & Post-Op Care
pre_op:
Preparation

  • Consent: Must be Voluntary, Informed (Risks/Benefits/Alternatives), and with Capacity.
  • Fasting (NPO): 2 hours for clear fluids, 6 hours for solids. Reduces aspiration risk.
  • VTE Prophylaxis: Mechanical (TEDs/SCDs) + Chemical (LMWH/Clexane). Assess bleeding risk.
  • Antibiotics: Prophylactic dose given at induction (within 60 mins of incision). Indicated for Clean-Contaminated and Contaminated cases.
  • Medications: Stop Anticoagulants (Warfarin/DOACs), Oral Hypoglycemics. Continue Beta-blockers, Steroids (may need stress dose).
post_op_fever:
The 5 W's of Post-Op Fever

  • Day 1-2 (Wind): Atelectasis (alveolar collapse due to pain/hypoventilation) or Pneumonia. Rx: Chest physio.
  • Day 3-5 (Water): Urinary Tract Infection (Catheter associated).
  • Day 5-7 (Wound): Surgical Site Infection (SSI). Redness, pain, pus. Rx: Remove sutures/Drain.
  • Day 7+ (Walk): Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT) / Pulmonary Embolism (PE).
  • Anytime (Wonder Drugs/What did we do): Drug fever, Cannula phlebitis, Anastomotic Leak, Abscess.
complications:
Classification

Immediate (<24h): Primary Hemorrhage, Reactionary Hemorrhage (slip of ligature/BP rise), Hypothermia, Aspiration.
Early (1-7 days): Fever 5 W's, Paralytic Ileus, Acute Urinary Retention, Confusion (Delirium).
Late (>7 days): Secondary Hemorrhage (infection eroding vessel), Wound Dehiscence, Incisional Hernia, Adhesions.

name: Chemotherapy Principles
classification:
Treatment Intent

  • Neoadjuvant: Given before surgery.
    - Goal: Downstage tumor (shrink it) to make inoperable tumors resectable, and treat micrometastases early. Common in Esophageal, Rectal, and Breast Ca.
  • Adjuvant: Given after surgery.
    - Goal: Kill remaining microscopic disease and prevent recurrence. Standard for Stage III Colon Ca, Breast Ca.
  • Palliative: For metastatic disease.
    - Goal: Symptom control and life extension. Not curative.
agents:
Common Drug Classes

Antimetabolites: 5-Fluorouracil (5-FU), Capecitabine. (GI Cancers).
Platinum Agents: Cisplatin, Oxaliplatin. (Cross-link DNA).
Taxanes: Docetaxel, Paclitaxel. (Microtubule inhibitors - Breast/Prostate).
Anthracyclines: Doxorubicin. (Cardiotoxic).
side_effects:
Toxicity

General: Nausea/Vomiting, Alopecia, Mucositis (mouth ulcers), Fatigue.
Bone Marrow Suppression: Anemia, Thrombocytopenia, Neutropenia.
Neutropenic Sepsis: Medical Emergency. Temp >38 + Neutrophils <0.5.
- Action: Resuscitate and give Broad Spectrum IV Antibiotics (e.g., Tazocin/Meropenem) within 1 hour. Do NOT wait for blood counts.

name: Sterilization & Disinfection
definitions:
Definitions

Cleaning: Physical removal of organic matter (blood/soil) using water/detergent. Essential first step.
Disinfection: Reduces number of viable organisms. May not kill spores/viruses. Used for skin, endoscopes.
Sterilization: Complete destruction of ALL micro-organisms including Spores and Prions. Mandatory for surgical instruments.
methods:
Sterilization Methods

  • Autoclave (Moist Heat): Steam under pressure. 121°C for 15 mins or 134°C for 3 mins. Gold standard for metal instruments. Kills spores.
  • Ethylene Oxide (Gas): For heat-sensitive items (plastics/tubing). Toxic/Flammable.
  • Gamma Irradiation: Industrial sterilization of single-use items (syringes, catheters).
disinfection_agents:
Disinfectants

Chlorhexidine: Binds to stratum corneum. Long acting. Alcohol-based is superior for skin prep.
Povidone Iodine: Broad spectrum but inactivated by organic matter (blood).
Glutaraldehyde (Cidex): High-level disinfectant for flexible endoscopes (heat sensitive). Toxic fumes.

name: Regions of the Abdomen
regions_9:
The 9 Regions

Divided by Mid-clavicular lines (vertical), Transpyloric plane (L1), and Transtubercular plane (L5).
  • Right Hypochondrium: Liver (Right lobe), Gallbladder, Hepatic flexure, Right Kidney/Adrenal.
  • Epigastrium: Stomach, Liver (Left lobe), Pancreas (Body/Tail), Duodenum (D1-D4), Transverse Colon, Aorta.
  • Left Hypochondrium: Spleen, Stomach (Fundus), Splenic flexure, Pancreas (Tail), Left Kidney.
  • Right Lumbar (Flank): Ascending Colon, Right Kidney, Small Intestine.
  • Umbilical: Small Intestine (Jejunum/Ileum), Transverse Colon, Aorta/IVC, Omentum.
  • Left Lumbar (Flank): Descending Colon, Left Kidney, Small Intestine.
  • Right Iliac Fossa (RIF): Cecum, Appendix, Terminal Ileum, Right Ovary/Tube.
  • Hypogastrium (Suprapubic): Bladder (if full), Uterus, Sigmoid Colon, Small Intestine.
  • Left Iliac Fossa (LIF): Sigmoid Colon, Left Ovary/Tube.
planes:
Key Landmarks

Transpyloric Plane (L1): Cuts through tips of 9th costal cartilages. Contains: Pylorus, Pancreas neck, SMA origin, Portal vein formation, Renal hila.
Mid-Inguinal Point: Halfway between ASIS and Pubic Symphysis (Femoral Artery).
McBurney's Point: 1/3 distance from ASIS to Umbilicus (Base of Appendix).

name: Anatomy of the Stomach
structure:
Gross Anatomy

Parts: Cardia, Fundus (gas bubble), Body (acid secretion), Antrum (grinding), Pylorus (sphincter).
Curvatures: Lesser (Right) and Greater (Left).
Omentum: Lesser Omentum attaches to Lesser Curve (contains Hepatogastric/Hepatoduodenal ligaments). Greater Omentum hangs from Greater Curve.
blood_supply:
Arterial Supply (Celiac Trunk)

  • Lesser Curvature: Left Gastric a. (Direct from Celiac) + Right Gastric a. (From Common Hepatic).
  • Greater Curvature: Left Gastroepiploic a. (From Splenic) + Right Gastroepiploic a. (From Gastroduodenal).
  • Fundus: Short Gastric arteries (From Splenic). Risk of ischemia during splenectomy if these are ligated.
Venous Drainage: Parallel to arteries, draining into Portal System. Left/Right Gastric veins drain directly to Portal Vein. Short Gastrics drain to Splenic Vein.
nerve_lymph:
Innervation & Lymphatics

Nerve: Vagus (CN X). Anterior Trunk (Left Vagus) & Posterior Trunk (Right Vagus). Gives 'Nerve of Latarjet' to antrum (motility) and branches to parietal cells (acid).
Lymph: Follows arteries.
- Virchow's Node: Left Supraclavicular node. Enlarged in metastatic Gastric Ca (Troisier's sign) due to spread via Thoracic Duct.

name: Anatomy of Hepatobiliary System
liver:
Liver Anatomy

Couinaud Segments: 8 functional segments based on vascular inflow (Portal v/Hepatic a) and biliary outflow.
- Caudate Lobe (I): Independent drainage to IVC.
- Left Lobe: Segments II, III, IV.
- Right Lobe: Segments V, VI, VII, VIII.
Ligaments: Falciform (divides anatomical lobes), Ligamentum Teres (remnant of umbilical vein), Coronary/Triangular ligaments.
biliary_tree:
Biliary Tract

Right & Left Hepatic Ducts -> Common Hepatic Duct (CHD). CHD joins Cystic Duct -> Common Bile Duct (CBD).
CBD: Runs in the free edge of the Lesser Omentum (Hepatoduodenal ligament) -> Behind D1 Duodenum -> Through Pancreas Head -> Joins Pancreatic Duct -> Ampulla of Vater.
Calot's Triangle: Boundaries: Liver edge (Sup), CHD (Med), Cystic Duct (Lat). Content: Cystic Artery, Lund's Node. (Critical view for Lap Chole).
variations:
Surgical Importance

Moynihan's Hump: Tortuous Right Hepatic Artery looping into Calot's triangle. Risk of injury.
Accessory Ducts (Luschka): Ducts in the gallbladder bed. Source of bile leak.

name: Anatomy of Alimentary Tract
small_bowel:
Jejunum vs Ileum

  • Jejunum (Proximal 2/5): Left upper quadrant. Thick wall, Wide lumen, Redder. Long vasa recta, Few arterial arcades. Mesentery has less fat (translucent windows).
  • Ileum (Distal 3/5): Right lower quadrant. Thin wall, Narrow lumen. Peyer's Patches (lymphoid tissue). Short vasa recta, Multiple arcades. Fatty mesentery. Site of B12/Bile salt absorption.
large_bowel:
Colon Features

Distinguished from small bowel by:
1. Taeniae Coli: 3 longitudinal muscle bands (converge at appendix base).
2. Haustra: Sacculations.
3. Appendices Epiploicae: Fat tags.
Blood Supply:
- SMA: Cecum, Ascending, Transverse (Proximal 2/3).
- IMA: Transverse (Distal 1/3), Descending, Sigmoid, Rectum.
- Marginal Artery of Drummond: Anastomosis between SMA and IMA.
rectum_anal:
Rectum & Anal Canal

Rectum: No Taeniae/Haustra. Peritoneum covers upper 1/3 (front/sides), middle 1/3 (front only), lower 1/3 (sub-peritoneal).
Anal Canal: Divided by Dentate Line.
- Above: Columnar, Visceral sensation (painless), Portal drainage.
- Below: Squamous, Somatic sensation (painful), Systemic drainage.
- Sphincters: Internal (Involuntary/Autonomic), External (Voluntary/Pudendal nerve).

name: Anatomy of Genitourinary System
kidney:
Kidneys

Retroperitoneal. T12-L3. Right is lower than Left (Liver).
Hilum Relations (Ant to Post): Renal Vein, Renal Artery, Renal Pelvis (VAP).
Coverings: Capsule -> Perirenal Fat -> Renal Fascia (Gerota's) -> Pararenal Fat.
ureter:
Ureters

25-30cm long muscular tubes. Retroperitoneal. Run on Psoas Major muscle.
Course: Cross over the Bifurcation of Common Iliac Arteries (Pelvic Brim). Pass under the Uterine Artery/Vas Deferens ("Water under the bridge").
Constrictions (Stone Impaction):
1. Pelvi-ureteric Junction (PUJ).
2. Pelvic Brim (Crossing Iliacs).
3. Vesico-ureteric Junction (VUJ - Narrowest point).
referred_pain:
Nerve Supply

Kidney (T10-L1) -> Pain radiates to Loin.
Ureter (T11-L2) -> Pain radiates Loin to Groin, Scrotum, or Labia (via Genitofemoral/Ilioinguinal nerves).

name: Inguinal Canal Anatomy
structure:
Boundaries (MALT Mnemonic)

  • Muscle (Roof): Internal Oblique & Transversus Abdominis fibers (arching over).
  • Aponeurosis (Anterior): External Oblique Aponeurosis.
  • Ligament (Floor): Inguinal Ligament (Poupart's) & Lacunar Ligament medially.
  • Transversalis (Posterior): Transversalis Fascia.
contents:
Canal Contents

Males: Spermatic Cord (Vas Deferens, Testicular Artery, Pampiniform Plexus, Genital Branch of Genitofemoral Nerve, Lymphatics).
Females: Round Ligament of Uterus.
Nerve: Ilioinguinal Nerve runs through the canal (on top of the cord), NOT inside the cord.
clinical_relevance:
Hernias

Deep Ring: Defect in Transversalis Fascia. Located at Mid-Inguinal Point (1.5cm above femoral pulse). Site of Indirect Inguinal Hernia (travels down canal).
Hesselbach's Triangle: Area of weakness in posterior wall. Medial to Inferior Epigastric vessels. Site of Direct Inguinal Hernia (bulges forward).

name: Femoral Triangle
contents:
Contents (NAVEL)

From Lateral to Medial:
1. Femoral Nerve (Outside sheath).
2. Femoral Artery.
3. Femoral Vein.
4. Empty Space (Femoral Canal).
5. Lymphatics (Cloquet's Node).
Femoral Sheath: Contains Artery, Vein, Canal. Nerve is NOT in the sheath.
clinical_relevance:
Femoral Hernia

Protrusion of bowel/omentum into the Femoral Canal.
Features: Below and Lateral to Pubic Tubercle.
Risks: High risk of strangulation due to rigid borders (Lacunar ligament medially, Inguinal ligament anteriorly). Surgery is mandatory.

name: Neck & Thyroid Anatomy
thyroid_relations:
Thyroid Gland

Two lobes + Isthmus. Enclosed in Pretracheal Fascia (moves with swallow).
Arterial: Superior Thyroid a. (Ext Carotid), Inferior Thyroid a. (Thyrocervical Trunk).
Venous: Superior/Middle (to IJV), Inferior (to Brachiocephalic).
Nerves:
- Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve (RLN): Runs in tracheoesophageal groove. Injury -> Hoarseness (unilateral) or Airway obstruction (bilateral).
- External Laryngeal Nerve: Supplies Cricothyroid (tensors cords). Injury -> Loss of high pitch voice.
triangles:
Surgical Triangles

Anterior Triangle: Midline, SCM, Mandible. Contains Carotid Sheath, Thyroid, Trachea.
Posterior Triangle: SCM, Trapezius, Clavicle. Contains Spinal Accessory Nerve (CN XI), Brachial Plexus, Subclavian vessels. CN XI is at risk during lymph node biopsy here (shoulder drop).

name: Breast & Axilla Anatomy
supply:
Vascular Supply

Arterial: Internal Thoracic (Mammary), Lateral Thoracic, Thoracoacromial, Intercostals.
Venous: Corresponding veins. Batson's Plexus (valveless vertebral veins) allows spread to spine.
lymphatics:
Lymph Drainage

75% to Axillary Nodes. 25% to Internal Mammary (Parasternal).
Axillary Levels (Berg's): Defined by Pectoralis Minor.
- Level I: Lateral to Pec Minor.
- Level II: Behind Pec Minor.
- Level III: Medial to Pec Minor (Apical).
nerves_at_risk:
Nerves in Axillary Clearance

1. Long Thoracic Nerve: Supplies Serratus Anterior. Injury -> Winged Scapula.
2. Thoracodorsal Nerve: Supplies Latissimus Dorsi. Injury -> Weak shoulder adduction/extension.
3. Intercostobrachial Nerve: Sensory to medial arm. Injury -> Numbness/Paresthesia.

name: Amoebic Liver Abscess
etiology:
Pathogen

Caused by Entamoeba histolytica protozoa. Transmission via fecal-oral route (cysts). Trophozoites invade colon (flask ulcers) -> portal vein -> liver (liquefactive necrosis).
clinical_features:
Presentation

Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) pain, high swinging fever, rigors, night sweats, weight loss.
Signs: Tender hepatomegaly, Intercostal tenderness. Anchovy Sauce Pus: Chocolate-colored, odorless, sterile pus (amoebae in wall).
management:
Treatment

Medical: Metronidazole 800mg TDS for 10 days (Cure >90%) + Diloxanide Furoate (clear gut cysts).
Aspiration: If High risk of rupture (Left lobe), No response to meds (72h), or Large (>10cm).

name: Gastric Outlet Obstruction
pathophysiology:
Causes

Benign: Pyloric stenosis from chronic PUD scarring (fibrosis).
Malignant: Ca Antrum or Ca Head of Pancreas.
Metabolic: Hypochloremic Metabolic Alkalosis with Paradoxical Aciduria (Kidney saves Na+ at expense of H+).
clinical_features:
Signs

Vomiting undigested food (non-bilious), Weight loss, Dehydration. Succussion Splash: Sloshing sound >4h post-meal. Visible Peristalsis (L to R).
management:
Plan

1. Resuscitation: IV Fluids (0.9% Saline + K+), NG Tube (Lavage/Decompression).
2. Diagnosis: OGDS.
3. Definitive: Balloon dilation (Benign) or Stent/Gastrojejunostomy (Malignant).

name: Fistula-in-Ano
etiology:
Cryptoglandular Theory

Infection of anal glands -> Intersphincteric Abscess -> Fistula tract. Associated with Crohn's, TB, Malignancy.
clinical_features:
Goodsall's Rule

Anterior openings: Track straight to dentate line.
Posterior openings: Track curved to posterior midline (6 o'clock).
Exception: Anterior openings >3cm from anal verge track posteriorly.
management:
Treatment

MRI Pelvis: Gold standard imaging.
Low Fistula: Fistulotomy (Lay open).
High Fistula: Seton (drainage/cutting), LIFT, Flap. (Preserve sphincter).

name: Diverticular Disease
pathology:
Pathogenesis

Acquired herniation of mucosa/submucosa through muscularis propria at vasa recta entry points. Sigmoid Colon is most affected (high pressure). Rectum is spared. Risk: Low fiber.
complications:
Sequelae

1. Diverticulitis: LIF pain, fever (Left sided appendicitis).
2. Perforation: Purulent or Fecal Peritonitis (Hinchey III/IV).
3. Bleeding: Massive painless hematochezia (arterial erosion).
4. Fistula: Colovesical (Pneumaturia/UTIs).
management:
Uncomplicated: Antibiotics (Amoxiclav + Metronidazole).
Abscess: CT-guided drainage.
Perforation: Hartmann's Procedure (Sigmoidectomy + End Colostomy).
Bleeding: Resuscitation, Embolization.

name: Hemorrhoids
anatomy:
Anal Cushions

Vascular cushions at 3, 7, 11 o'clock.
Internal: Above dentate line (Columnar, Visceral innervation - Painless).
External: Below dentate line (Squamous, Somatic innervation - Painful).
clinical_features:
Symptoms: Bright red bleeding (splash), Prolapse, Pruritus, Mucus. Pain ONLY if thrombosed.
Grading: I (Bleed), II (Spontaneous reduction), III (Manual reduction), IV (Irreducible).
management:
Conservative: Fiber, fluids.
Office: Rubber Band Ligation (Gold standard I/II).
Surgical: Hemorrhoidectomy (Milligan-Morgan) or Stapled (PPH) for Grade III/IV.

name: Skin Malignancies
types:
Basal Cell Carcinoma (BCC)

Most common. From basal layer. Pearly nodule, rolled edge, telangiectasia. Locally invasive (Rodent ulcer) but no mets. Rx: Excision with 3-4mm margin.

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC)

From keratinocytes. Everted edge, keratin pearl. Marjolin's Ulcer: SCC arising in chronic scar/burn. Aggressive. Mets to lymph nodes. Rx: Wide excision (1cm margin).

Melanoma

From melanocytes. ABCDE rule (Asymmetry, Border, Color, Diameter, Evolution). Prognosis depends on Breslow Thickness. Rx: Wide excision + Sentinel Node Biopsy.

name: Flail Chest
pathophysiology:
Mechanism

Fracture of 3+ consecutive ribs in 2+ places. Creates floating segment.
Paradoxical Respiration: Segment moves IN on inspiration, OUT on expiration.
Hypoxia: Primarily due to underlying Pulmonary Contusion (shunting) and pain (splinting), not just chest wall mechanics.
management:
Priorities

1. Analgesia: Epidural or Paravertebral block is crucial to allow coughing/breathing.
2. Oxygen/CPAP: Positive pressure splints the chest.
3. Intubation: If respiratory failure ensues.

name: Intussusception
clinical_features:
Presentation

Telescoping of bowel (Ileum into Cecum). Peak age 3-9 months.
Triad: 1. Intermittent colicky pain (screaming/legs up). 2. Redcurrant jelly stool (late sign). 3. Sausage-shaped mass (RUQ) + Empty RIF (Sign of Dance).
management:
Investigation: USG ('Target' or 'Doughnut' sign).
Treatment:
- Air/Barium Enema: Diagnostic and Therapeutic. Success >80%. Contraindicated if peritonitis.
- Surgery: If enema fails or peritonitis. Manual reduction or resection (if lead point present).

name: Varicocele
anatomy:
Pathology

Dilatation of pampiniform plexus. 90% Left sided.
Why Left? Left Testicular vein drains vertically into Renal Vein (high pressure) vs Right drains obliquely into IVC. Also compressed by SMA ('Nutcracker').
management:
Signs: 'Bag of worms', cough impulse, disappears supine.
Red Flag: Sudden onset Left varicocele or ANY Right varicocele suggests Renal Cell Carcinoma (tumor thrombus).
Indication for Rx: Pain, Infertility (heat kills sperm), Testicular atrophy.

name: Hydronephrosis
etiology:
Causes

Unilateral: Stone (Ureteric), Stricture, TCC Ureter, Pelvi-ureteric Junction Obstruction (PUJO).
Bilateral: Bladder Outflow Obstruction (BPH, Ca Prostate), Urethral Stricture, Retroperitoneal Fibrosis.
management:
Investigation: USG (dilation), CT KUB (stones), MAG3 Renogram (functional obstruction).
Treatment: Relieve obstruction.
- Upper: JJ Stent or Nephrostomy.
- Lower: Catheter ( urethral/suprapubic).

name: Keloid vs Hypertrophic Scar
comparison:
Keloid

Overgrowth of dense collagen (Type I/III). Extends beyond original wound boundaries. No regression. High recurrence. Sites: Sternum, Earlobes, Deltoid. Genetic predisposition.

Hypertrophic Scar

Confined within wound boundaries. Occurs at sites of tension. Often regresses spontaneously with time.
management:
Keloid: Intralesional Steroids (Triamcinolone). Pressure garments. Excision ALONE has >50% recurrence (must combine with adjuvant therapy).
Hypertrophic: Silicone gel, pressure.
